channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Jacob Blake, Rare Survivor at Center of Police Protests, Starts Telling His Own Story
item.description: In a video recorded from his hospital bed, Mr. Blake, who was shot by the police, says, “It hurts to breathe; it hurts to sleep.”
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs

item.title: California Wildfires: Extreme Heat Turns State Into a Furnace
item.description: Fires burning from near the Mexico border to the forests of the Sierra Nevada spread a curtain of smoke over California on Monday.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy, Kate Taylor and Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Josh Edelson/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A firefighter doused flames as they pushed towards homes in Madera County, Calif., on Monday.

item.title: A New Front in Coronavirus Pandemic: College Towns
item.description: The coronavirus is spiking around campuses from Texas to Iowa to North Carolina as students return.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Watson, Shawn Hubler, Danielle Ivory and Robert Gebeloff
item.media:credit: Kathryn Gamble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Downtown Iowa City on Thursday. Iowa City is a full-blown pandemic hot spot — one of about 100 college communities around the country where infections have spiked in recent weeks.

item.title: After Jacob Blake Shooting, Kenosha Wrestles With Its Future
item.description: Some residents saw the shooting of Jacob Blake as proof that the city’s policing needs a fundamental overhaul. Others spoke of getting back to normal.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker blasts graffiti from the pavement at Civic Center Park in Kenosha, Wis., Wednesday. The next step has left Kenosha a city divided.

item.title: Manhattan’s Office Buildings Are Empty. But for How Long?
item.description: As they grow accustomed to working from home, many businesses are delaying signing new leases until rents drop and the pandemic passes.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell and Peter Eavis
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

item.title: In Georgia, Officials Are Investigating Hundreds of Cases of Double Voting
item.description: Georgia’s secretary of state, Brad Raffensperger, said that 1,000 people voted twice in the state’s June primary and August runoff elections, and warned that “we will prosecute.”
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brad Raffensperger, Georgia’s secretary of state, held a news conference Tuesday to announce that investigations were underway in 100 of the state’s 159 counties.

item.title: New Hampshire Primary Elections Test the Influence of Trump and Sanders
item.description: As voters cast ballots today, the Democratic governor’s race and the Republican Senate contest may help preview the parties’ future in the presidential swing state.
item.dc:creator: Trip Gabriel
item.media:credit: Kristopher Radder/The Brattleboro Reformer, via Associated Press
item.media:description: New Hampshire primary voters were choosing candidates for governor and Senate on Tuesday.

item.title: Will Doug Emhoff’s Legal Career Be an Issue for the Biden-Harris Ticket?
item.description: Mr. Emhoff, the husband of Senator Kamala Harris, has a long record as a litigator at two of the nation’s top firms, posing potential conflicts that could draw scrutiny from both Republicans and liberal Democrats alike.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul, Kenneth P. Vogel and Danny Hakim
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Douglas Emhoff with his wife, Senator Kamala Harris, after she accepted the Democratic nomination for vice president last month.

item.title: The Climate Connection to California’s Wildfires
item.description: As fires spread through California during a global pandemic, read some of our past coverage about what’s causing them and what might help contain them.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Marcio Jose Sanchez/Associated Press
item.media:description: Firefighters used drip torches to start a controlled burn to contain the Creek Fire in Shaver Lake, Calif., on Sunday.

item.title: Crazy Weather in Colorado: Roasting Yesterday, Snowing Today
item.description: Temperatures plunged more than 50 degrees overnight as an Arctic air mass drove into the Denver area, bringing a very early winter storm on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy
item.media:credit: David Zalubowski/Associated Press
item.media:description: Smoke from the Cameron Peak wildfire occluded the skyline of downtown Denver on Sunday.

item.title: Republicans Revive 2018 Election Strategy: Scare Voters
item.description: President Trump and his party are using a playbook that aims to alarm people about crime in their backyards. It didn’t work in 2018, but both parties think it could resonate more this year.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy W. Peters
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Like in 2018, President Trump and Republicans are using a fear-based playbook to win over voters in 2020.

item.title: Selling the Census Last Minute, With Cowboys and Sudoku
item.description: Worried that people won’t be counted, community groups and local governments are spending big to get the word out. “It’s an absolute panic,” one executive said.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu
item.media:credit: FCB Chicago
item.media:description: With just a few weeks remaining, officials in Chicago and other cities have worked to increase census response rates.

item.title: Signs That Define a Building, and Sometimes a City
item.description: Building signs have grown into a $37.5 billion industry. Some have become so iconic they are permanent parts of the landscape, often standing in for their hometowns.
item.dc:creator: Jane Margolies

item.title: A New Theory Asks: Could a Mask Be a Crude ‘Vaccine’?
item.description: Scientists float a provocative — and unproven — idea: that masks expose the wearer to just enough of the virus to spark a protective immune response.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.media:credit: Daniel Acker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new scientific paper explores the concept of variolation, the deliberate exposure to a pathogen to generate a protective immune response.

item.title: What We Know About the Death of George Floyd in Minneapolis
item.description: Mr. Floyd died after being handcuffed and pinned to the ground by an officer’s knee in an episode that was captured on video, touching off nationwide protests.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The killing of George Floyd led to large protests against police brutality and systemic racism in more than 150 American cities.

item.title: Wildfires Live Updates: Helicopter Rescue Missions and Power Shutoffs in California
item.description: Extreme weather is battering the Western United States, with fires raging along the Pacific Coast and snow falling in Colorado.
item.media:credit: Josh Edelson/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: In a closely watched New Hampshire primary, Democrats will pick a challenger to Governor Sununu.
item.description: the
item.dc:creator: Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Maddie Meyer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Gov. Chris Sununu of New Hampshire campaigned at New Hampshire Motor Speedway last month.

item.title: Ayad Akhtar to Lead PEN America
item.description: The Pulitzer-winning playwright, whose new book, “Homeland Elegies,” comes out this month, succeeds the novelist Jennifer Egan at the literary organization.
item.dc:creator: John Williams
item.media:credit: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Literature has a place in our national life,” Ayad Akhtar said. “It can be part of our national discourse and can contribute to it in interesting ways.”

item.title: California Wildfires: State of Emergency Declared in Five Counties
item.description: Tuesday: Over the holiday weekend, another record-shattering heat wave slammed the West Coast and new fires erupted across California.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: John Antczak/Associated Press
item.media:description: Smoke from wildfires burning east of Los Angeles dimmed the sunrise on Monday, seen from Pasadena.

item.title: Pence and Harris vied for Wisconsin, a pivotal state in the 2020 race.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris toured a union training center in Milwaukee on Monday after meeting supporters.

item.title: Israel’s Coronavirus Czar Clashes With Ultra-Orthodox, a Netanyahu Ally
item.description: As he moved to slow the pandemic, Dr. Ronni Gamzu kept butting heads with ultra-Orthodox leaders. Then Israel’s top virus fighter was suddenly undercut.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Abir Sultan/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Dr. Ronni Gamzu, waving the Israeli flag, became Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s virus czar after pioneering a program to protect the elderly from the virus at Ichilov Hospital in Tel Aviv.

item.title: The Trump campaign’s lavish spending eroded its head start, a Times analysis shows.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally for President Trump in Latrobe, Pa., last week. Mr. Trump’s campaign has spent $800 million.

item.title: Trump lashes out at Biden and Harris and chides a reporter for wearing a mask.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni and Andy Newman
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump called a news conference at the White House on Monday to insult his opponents and air some grievances.

item.title: Kamala Harris Visits Wisconsin
item.description: Harris and Pence come to Wisconsin bearing two very different messages, while Biden and Trump accuse each other of politicizing the virus.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: Conservatives for Labor
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Union members held a caravan rally in Washington this summer.

item.title: Covid-19 News: Live Updates
item.description: Nine drug companies issued a joint pledge that they would “stand with science” and not put forward a vaccine until it had been thoroughly vetted. A political uproar quashed plans for targeted lockdowns in Israel.
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: What Month Is It? Pandemic Scrambles the Travel Calendar
item.description: With more families working and studying remotely, resorts are dangling attractive rates, enhanced Wi-Fi and the charms of autumn as reasons to forget summer is ending.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: At Least 37 Million People Have Been Displaced by America’s War on Terror
item.description: A new report calculates the number of people who fled because of wars fought by the United States since Sept. 11, 2001.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:credit: Mohamed Abdiwahab/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Somali woman carried wood to make a shelter in a camp for internally displaced people in December 2018.

item.title: It’s Not Easy to Get a Coronavirus Test for a Child
item.description: As schools reopen, many parents still can’t find a test nearby, impeding the fight against the virus.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kliff and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.media:credit: Elaine Thompson/Associated Press
item.media:description: Many coronavirus testing sites do not screen children. One that does, outside Chief Sealth High School in Seattle, swabbed 1-year-old Quentin Brown late last month.

item.title: Black, Native American and Fighting for Recognition in Indian Country
item.description: Enslaved people were also driven west along the Trail of Tears. After a historic Supreme Court ruling, their descendants are fighting to be counted as tribal members.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy

item.title: ‘Or I Will Stab You Right Now’: A Family’s Prison Extortion Nightmare
item.description: While serving time, Ryan Rust was beaten, stabbed and threatened with hot oil if his relatives didn’t pay up. After disturbing calls and texts, they bought guns for protection.
item.dc:creator: Serge F. Kovaleski and Dan Barry
item.media:credit: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times

item.title: Father Michel J. Mulloy Resigns Weeks Before Becoming Bishop of Duluth
item.description: Father Michel J. Mulloy had been chosen by Pope Francis to lead the Diocese of Duluth, Minn., but then an allegation from the 1980s surfaced, church officials said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Diocese of Duluth
item.media:description: Former Bishop-elect Michel J. Mulloy

item.title: Gender-Reveal Party Is Blamed in California Wildfire
item.description: The El Dorado fire in California ignited as a family was using a “pyrotechnic device” to announce the gender of a new baby, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales and Allyson Waller
item.media:credit: Ringo H.W. Chiu/Associated Press
item.media:description: The authorities said the El Dorado fire near Yucaipa, Calif., started as the result of a gender-reveal party.

item.title: Pence and Harris Vie for Wisconsin as Trump Vents From the White House
item.description: The unofficial Labor Day kickoff to the fall campaign centered on Pennsylvania and Wisconsin, two pivotal states for both the president and Joseph R. Biden Jr.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Kamala Harris toured a union training center in Milwaukee on Monday after meeting supporters.

item.title: How Trump’s Billion-Dollar Campaign Lost Its Cash Advantage
item.description: Five months ago, President Trump’s re-election campaign had a huge financial edge over Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s. The Times conducted an extensive review of how the Trump team spent lavishly to show how that advantage evaporated.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally for President Trump in Latrobe, Pa., last week. Mr. Trump’s campaign has spent $800 million.
